page.title: 06Ecology of Melchbourne
page.content: The area is still relatively unspoilt. Melchbourne Woods have been well managed and a good deal of new tree planting has taken place. The wood is a mixture of coniferous and deciduous trees. Lent Lillies, amongst other wild flowers can be seen there. The Bedford Natural History Society spent an evening watching the bats and moths there. The lake in Melchbourne Park is a breeding place for crested grebe, pochard, tufted ducks and mallards. There is a good mix of arable and pasture land and many of the hedges, small copses and ponds have been retained, making the area a haven for small mammals, insects and birds. Badgers have been seen in the area. The largest farm in the area, Melchbourne Estate, is undertaking a tree planting scheme.
